As part of the throwback stories Karim Zeroual also shared his favourite memories from Blackpool week in 2019.
The presenter, 31, said: 'The most memorable part for me was actually making it to Blackpool because I knew how much it meant to my dance partner, Amy Dowden MBE. 
'Blackpool has a special place in her heart since she's competed there before and dreamed of performing there on Strictly. 
'It was an incredible moment for both of us, and prepping for our Charleston felt different – so much bigger, grander, with a lot more going on than a typical week.
'And having the other celebs and pros there felt like a school trip, which was a lot of fun.'
It comes after the dances for the show were revealed as the series takes a trip to the Tower Ballroom and the eight remaining couples must do all they can to impress.
For Blackpool week, Montell Douglas and Johannes Radebe will bring the heat with a Salsa to Don't Leave Me This Way by Thelma Houston, while Sarah Hadland and Vito Coppola will deliver a Couples' Choice routine to Padam Padam by Kylie Minogue.

 Strictly Come Dancing Blackpool special songs and dances are REVEALED - as an iconic boy band gets set to perform in the Tower Ballroom 
Meanwhile the guest performance act for the Blackpool special are none other than the legendary Pet Shop Boys.
On Saturday night, they will open the show with a medley of some of their greatest hits, with the Strictly professional dancers joining them for an opening number.
Then, on Sunday night's Results Show, they will perform their brand-new single All The Young Dudes. 
The highly anticipated professional dancers' performance at Blackpool's prestigious Tower Ballroom will feature an Argentine Tango set in a glamorous 1940s hotel.
Choreographed by Matt Flint, Leandro Palou, and Maria Tsiatsiani, the routine will showcase the show's talented professional dancers alongside supporting extra dancers. 
Set to the sultry sounds of Tango Jalousie, the performance promises to immerse the audience in a world of vintage glamour and intense passion.

news.title: Why Trump chose RFK Jr. for HHS secretary
news.text:
Why Trump chose RFK Jr. for HHS secretary
 President-elect Donald Trump's selection of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as Health and Human Services secretary came following several other controversial choices for Cabinet members. Caitlin Huey-Burns takes a look at the president-elect's decision-making process.
news.summary: President-elect Donald Trump's selection of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as Health and Human Services secretary came following several other controversial choices for Cabinet members. Caitlin Huey-Burns takes a look at the president-elect's decision-making process.

news.title: Trump taps RFK Jr. as HHS secretary
news.text:
Trump taps RFK Jr. as HHS secretary
 President-elect Donald Trump announced Thursday that he has selected Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as his pick to run the Department of Health and Human Services. Kennedy, who ended his longshot independent presidential bid and endorsed Trump, has a history of being a vaccine skeptic and making false claims about public health. Dr. Jon LaPook takes a look at what it could mean for health care in the U.S.

news.title: Former U.S. attorney explains why he calls Matt Gaetz the "anti-attorney general"
news.text:
Former U.S. attorney explains why he calls Matt Gaetz the "anti-attorney general"
 President-elect Donald Trump nominated former Rep. Matt Gaetz as his attorney general. Former U.S. attorney and assistant deputy attorney general Harry Litman joins CBS News to discuss his column calling Gaetz the "anti-attorney general" and what to expect from his potential management of the Justice Department.

news.title: Oil Heads for Weekly Drop as Glut Concerns and Dollar Take Toll
news.text:
Commodities including crude have struggled this week as a gauge of the dollar rallied to the highest in two years, powering upward in the aftermath of Donald Trump’s election victory. The US currency is set for its seventh weekly gain, making raw materials more expensive for most buyers.

Crude has been alternating between weekly gains and losses since mid-October, buffeted by tensions in the Middle East, the prospect of oversupply going into next year, and shifts in currency markets. Chinese consumption has also been a major focus, and industrial production data due later on Friday will give traders fresh insights into demand trends in the top importer.

Elsewhere, US oil stockpiles rose by about 2.1 million barrels last week, above an industry estimate, There was also a major, 4.4-million-barrel gasoline draw, which cut holdings to the lowest in a decade for this time of the year.

To get Bloomberg’s Energy Daily newsletter into your inbox, click here.
news.summary: Oil headed for a weekly drop, weighed down by the impact of a stronger dollar and concerns the global market will flip to a glut next year.
news.author: Bloomberg News
